11.10 AM: The 5am update from the National Hurricane Centre had Gustav 100 miles south of New Orleans and 40 miles south-east of Port Fourchon, Louisiana. In the past hour a station in south-west Louisiana reported a sustained wind of 91mph.

11.25 AM: If you weren't aware of the naming convention for hurricanes, here's a brief explanation. The World Meteorological Organisation assigns six lists of names. One is used each year and then the cycle begins again, reverting to the first list.
So there was actually a Gustav in 2002, although it is possible the name may be retired this year as is the custom when a particularly destructive hurricane hits (Katrina for instance). For New Orleans' sake let's hope this is not the last hurricane Gustav.

11.45 AM: Above is footage of when Gustav hit Cuba. No deaths were reported in the country, which is renowned for its expertise in responding to hurricanes.

12.15 PM: A detailed update has been released by the National Hurricane Centre. It says the eye of Gustav is nearing the Louisiana coast and it is 85 miles south of New Orleans. It will cross the Louisiana coast by midday. Wind gusts of 63mph have been reported and the NHC is predicting total rainfall accumulations of six to 12 inches over parts of Louisiana. "Preparations to protect life and property should have been completed," it warns. The next intermediary advisory will be released in two hours time and the next complete one in four hours time.

12.25 PM: I should have added that the NHC said "no significant change is strength is likely before landfall". That means it will remain a category 3 storm. But remember Katrina was category three when it came ashore.

12.55 PM: A map of the hurricane's projected path on Reuters shows it passing west of New Orleans although the city lies within its "potential path" on the graphic.
Reuters also reports that news that there are no signs of the hurricane strengthening has seen oil prices fall.

"Gustav is the biggest threat to the region -- home to a quarter of U.S. oil output and 15 percent of natural gas output -- since Hurricanes Katrina and Rita wrecked more than 100 offshore oil platforms in 2005 and closed several large refineries for months," it says.

1.20 PM: On the micro-blogging site Twitter, dilberger, who is in the French quarter writes that winds and "semi heavy rains" have been going for about 90 minutes and that the electricity has gone off within the last hour. On his myspace page, where he adopts the pseudonym Haywire, he estimates those remaining in New Orleans as 50% police/military, 40% media and 10% non-evacuees. He has posted a video from yesterday illustrating his point as he rides around the city on his bike "documenting the documentors".

2.05 PM: Nobody died when Gustav hit Cuba at the weekend, but huge trees were uprooted in the capital Havana and 240,000 people were evacuated from Pinar del Rio province, the Chicago Tribune's man in Havana reported.

2.15 PM:
Just in from Reuters citing the NHC: Gustav has been downgraded to category 2.

2.30 PM: The updated NHC advisory also says that there no significant strengthening of the storm expected before landfall and it is likely to weaken as it moves inland. The hurricane is moving at 16mph and is about 80 miles south/south-east of New Orleans. Maximum sustained wind speeds have fallen to 110mph, which puts it at the upper end of category 2 of the Saffir-Simpson scale.

2.35 PM: The downgrading of the storm is good news from residents in threatened areas, both humans and beasts. A website has actually been set up specially for pets endangered by the hurricane with the catch line "Helping Hurricane Gustav Pets". Apparently Florida Association Kennel Club volunteers arrived in New Orleans to commemorate Katrina but have instead turned their attentions to Gustav.

2.50 PM: Earlier, I linked to Marc Cooper's blog on the Huffington Post suggesting Gustav would be another nail in the coffin of the Republican administration by presenting a reminder of the failures following Katrina. But another perspective, presented by David Nather on CQ politics is that there are opportunities for John McCain "to demonstrate how he would change the party and distance it from the Bush years". It has also saved the presumptive Republican candidate the embarrassment of an appearance by the hugely unpopular Bush at the Republican convention.

3.00 PM: Dragon X has posted some interesting photos of Louisiana as it awaits the storm, on Flickr. One shows a man enjoying a beer on a wet street outside a bar in the French quarter of New Orleans. Surely it's a bit early in the day for a beer?

3.15 PM: anneinlondon, in response to your comment, apparently prisoners were moved out on Thursday and Friday and are being moved to various facilities, not just Angola prison, further inland. According to nola.com 300 of the 2,500 inmates were being released and the remaining 2,200 were evacuated.

3.30 PM: The Lafayette Advertiser warns that, despite the downgrade to a category 2 storm, flooding is a real risk. It says that a slowing of Gustav's speed could lead to major flooding tomorrow and on Wednesday across inland Louisiana, north-eastern and parts of eastern Texas and southern Arkansas. It adds there could be 10-20 inches of rain over parts of Louisiana and southern Mississippi and East Texas.

3.45 PM: There have been concerns that despite the levees being reinforced since Katrina, they might not hold. But a reporter from Louisiana station WWLTV.com was on the west bank of New Orleans where she said a potentially vulnerable levee was holding.

3.55 PM: In an interview with WWLTV New Orleans mayor Ray Nagin said a major fire had been contained. More worryingly he said water had been "overtopping" flood walls on the industrial canal but had not breached them and two small ships and a barge had broken loose and could bang against the flood walls. Despite the downgrading of the hurricane, he said:

We are nowhere near out of danger yet.

Nagin said there were also power outages, particularly on the east bank. WWLTV expects between six and 12 inches between now and tomorrow evening, although 20 inches is a possibility in some areas.

He raised the possibility of major returns of people to the city on Thursday and people moving back as early as Wednesday. Nagin said the two points of concern were the west bank and the industrial canal.

We are not out of the woods, that's the main message I want everyone to understand.

4.20 PM: Electricity provider Entergy says a quarter of a million customers are without supplies.

Meanwhile, the latest advisory from the NHC has the centre of Gustav making landfall near Cocodrie, Louisiana. It is 70 miles south-west of New Orleans, travelling at about 15mph, and is expected to track along the south central Louisiana coast this afternoon, then move into western Louisiana tonight and eastern Texas on Tuesday. Maximum sustained winds are near 110mph but it is forecast to weaken.

4.25 PM: The Associated Press has army corps saying levees are holding in New Orleans and elsewhere.

4.30 PM: On gustavbloggers.com some recent photos have been posted.

It notes elsewhere on the site that, unlike when Katrina hit, mobile phones are working. It explains that the reason is that so many people have left town so the network is not overwhelmed.

4.40 PM: On New Orleans metblogs there is a complaint about CNN running the headline: "Floodwaters overtop industrial canal levee in New Orleans. Richard writes that it is "hysteria-inducing".

Sky has been showing film of the water going over the wall for the past 15 minutes or so but there is still no report of a breach.

On WWLTV a councillor said that the boats in the industrial canal are not a threat and remarkably, given the conditions, that a diver is in the canal trying to see what can be done to resolve the situation.

4.50 PM: The "first video of Gustav" on the LA coast can be seen on the weather channel, which is also an invaluable resource of maps charting the actual and potential path of Gustav.

5.10 PM:
The prize for intrepid reporter must go to Chris Kirkham from the Times-Picayune paper who is blogging from a large shrimp boat called the Mister Jug. He is even taking questions.

5.20 PM:
We don't know whether this is in dubious taste or not, but Kauz.com, a TV station serving Wichita Falls, Texas, has a poll with the question: Would you rather watch Hurricane Gustav or the Republican National Convention? It rather sums up John McCain's problems. Talk about raining on the Republican parade.

5.35 PM:
George Bush, who made such a hash of Katrina three years ago, has attended a briefing by emergency officials in Texas. Seeking to make amends for Katrina - and to show that his party can learn from its mistakes - the president warned: "This storm has yet to pass. It's a serious event." He insisted that coordination of the emergency response to Gustav "is a lot better than during Katrina."

5.40 PM:
As Sky News gives us wall-to-wall coverage of Gustav making landfall in the US, media commentator Roy Greenslade wonders whether it's all hype and hot air. Why didn't the media rush to the Caribbean or Cuba, Greenslade wonders. Well Newsblog tried to rectify matters in its own way by including a reference to the damage in Cuba. But surely Greenslade knows why this is so. The US is where the TV stations are. And it's cheaper to cover a natural disaster - if it turns out that way - on your own doorstep.

6.00 PM:
This from the Ministry of Defence. The Royal Navy has sent one of its ships to help. HMS Iron Duke - on which Prince William recently spent some time - is nomnally involved in drugs interdiction. But it will provide help if needed.

"What we bring is a range of skills coupled with professional and motivated sailors, who if faced with difficult circumstances, are able to assist," said the ship's captain, Commander Mark Newland.

6.15 PM:
Michael Moore, the documentary film-maker, has written "an open letter to God" as a mock act of repentance for telling MSNBC that Gustav's timing, coinciding with the Republican convention, was divine intervention.

"Please God, let the storm die out at sea. It's done enough damage already. If you do this one favour for me, I promise not to invoke your name again."

6.35 PM:
It looks like New Orleans has been spared a full frontal assault by Gustav, which made landfall near Cocodrie, southwest of the city.

Water sloshed over the top of a canal floodwall, but city officials and the Army Corps of Engineers said they expected the levees, still only partially rebuilt after Katrina, would hold.

"We are seeing some overtopping waves," Colonel Jeff Bedey, commander of the Corps' hurricane protection office, told the Associated Press. "We are cautiously optimistic and confident that we won't see catastrophic wall failure."

The extent of the damage in Cajun country was not immediately clear, and only one storm-related death, involving a woman killed in a car wreck, was reported in Louisiana. Still, the storm could prove devastating to the region of fishing villages and oil-and-gas towns, AP reports.

As the red carpet is readied for the 17th anniversary of Uzbekistan's independence from the Soviet Union on September 1, for the majority of the population the euphoria of the freedom celebrations is countered by the ruthless suppression of citizen and civil society freedoms.

The constitution of Uzbekistan emphatically guarantees citizens the right to engage in public life by holding rallies, meetings and demonstrations. In practice, however, any attempts by citizens to peacefully gather to express opinions on public affairs are consistently met with stiff official resistance and hurriedly dispersed by government troops. Democratic dissent is countered by official intimidation and harassment including arbitrary detention. Activist Mutabar Tojiboyeva, who was awarded this year's Martin Ennals award for human rights, was forced to spend nearly three years in prison because she dared to question the tragic 2005 massacre of over 500 protestors by security forces in Andijan. To date, no officials have been held responsible for the widespread loss of life. Mutabar was providing support to the victims and their family members at the time of her arrest. She was ill-treated and subject to constant torture in prison. As a result, her health deteriorated significantly. Mutabar was finally released in March this year after considerable international pressure. Although she continues to serve a suspended sentence, she remains firm in her resolve to continue to speak out against official excesses.

At the time of writing, another civil society voice, poet and thinker Yusuf Juma, who had the courage to protest peacefully against the controversial re-election of President Karimov in December 2007, is currently serving a four-year prison term. Juma's family alleges that he has been tortured severely. His 22-year-old son, who was also arrested by the authorities, is missing. The official version is that he escaped. The family fears much worse.
The extent of suppression of civil liberties in Uzbekistan can be gauged by the restrictive Rules of Holding Mass Events brought into force in 2003 to regulate the freedom of assembly. The rules avoid any mention of the constitutional freedom to organise street marches, pickets and demonstrations. Instead, the definition of mass events is limited to "theatrical entertainment, concert, sport, advertising and other entertaining programmes, along with the celebration of national, religious and professional events". As a result, the legislation fails to recognise legitimate forms of public protest that are both regionally and internationally accepted. In addition, organisers are required to obtain permission from the authorities to hold any event at least one month in advance. The application is then passed through various government departments in a complicated and time-consuming approval process. Even if an event is allowed, representatives from the secret service and the Ministry of the Interior then maintain constant surveillance during the proceedings for possible threats to "social order and safety". They are allowed to summarily call off an event at any time. Additionally, to keep public assemblies under constant surveillance, organisers of mass events are required to allocate a minimum of 10 seats in each section and a seat in each row for members of the territorial organs of the internal security services and the national security service.

Moreover, there are severe restrictions on the freedom to associate and carry out civil society activities. NGOs must compulsorily register before being allowed to function. Permission to register is often subjectively denied, particularly to those organisations that are likely to offer independent views and legitimate criticism of official policies. For instance, pickets and demonstrations organised by the unregistered Human Rights Defenders Alliance of Uzbekistan in the last three years have been constantly disbanded by the police and national security service troops, followed by arrests and physical assaults on participants. After each weekly protest, these human rights defenders are detained for periods ranging from hours to several days. Their homes are under constant surveillance. Random searches and administrative penalties are routine occurrences. Aside from NGOs, faith-based groups and professional associations also undergo extensive scrutiny and harassment. Between 2003 to 2007, there were 300 confirmed closures of civil society organisations.

Given the prevailing environment, independence day celebrations ring hollow. If freedom is to be truly realised, constitutional rights must be a living reality for the people and civil society of Uzbekistan, rather than mere promises on paper.

Some of my liberal pals are nervous and think that the GOP's reasonably sensitive handling of the Gustav situation is a godsend for them. McCain and co. get to look compassionate, even like they care about black people (!), and normal Americans will just wilt at the sight of McCain's restrained stateliness.

I don't buy it for a second. As a general rule, when politicians act stately in public, they're terrified of something in private. Republicans are terrified in general of the memory of Katrina. And specifically, they're terrified of this. Click on it and take a look. It was snapped just as Katrina was closing in on the Gulf Coast shore. If the GOP went ahead with its convention as normal, I presume that photo would be in an Obama ad in no time. That's point number one.

Point number two: The real reason for this convention is not to push the GOP's positive agenda. That's a nice side story. But the real reason to have a four-day Muslim-unpatriot-a-pollooza. This is what Dick Cheney and, in a more restrained and presidential way, George Bush were supposed to do Monday night. It is surely what Rudy Giuliani and Joe Liberman are supposed to do Tuesday night, if Tuesday evening's session still comes off.

The Republicans' best shot at winning this November is to raise questions about Obama in the minds of enough voters. They can win, in other words, only be going negative. Therefore, every minute of Obama-hating on national TV the GOP loses is a minute that helps the Democratic candidate. Ideally from Obama's perspective, and assuming of course a minimum loss of property and life, the optimal result is no convention Monday and Tuesday nights. Let Palin and McCain speak. She'll come across as the lightweight she is, and he'll be seen as conducting a salvaging operation.

The one danger for Democrats is that somehow the Republicans manage to turn their convention into a virtual telethon for hurricane victims, which actually might fool some people and produce a silver lining for them. But they're not canceling their sessions because they think it's the noble thing to do. They're canceling them because politically, they have no choice. There is no way they could be putting on a convention while the Gulf coast flooded. Go look at that photograph again.
